headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext:
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Lenovo Fiscal Year 2010 and '11 Annual Results Presentation. I would also like to welcome our participants on the live webcast. Before we begin, let me introduce our senior management on stage. Sitting in the middle is Lenovo's Chairman, Mr. Liu Chuanzhi. Next to him, our Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Yang Yuanqing. Next to him is our Chief Operating Officer, Mr. Rory Read. And on the other side, we have our Chief Financial Officer, Mr. Wong Wai Ming. 
I'd like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Yuanqing now. He is going to give us his remarks on the group in the past fiscal year. Yuanqing, please.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext:
Good evening, everybody. So thank you for joining us. This has been a fantastic year for Lenovo. So let's get started. So we had a very strong fourth quarter to close outstanding fiscal year. Lenovo was the fastest growing major PC company for the 6th straight quarter. We also had a strong improvement in our gross profit margin of almost 2 points year-on-year. 
For the year, Lenovo grew 4x the market read, and our market share reached a all-time high of 10.2%. For the first time, we have surpassed USD $20 billion revenue, reached $21 billion. And our PTI doubled to USD $358 million. We also achieved a historic low E/R [Expenses-to-Revenue] ratio, just over 9%, even after substantial investments in branding and in innovation.
If you look deeper, the story is even better. For the year, Lenovo was #1 in global emerging markets, including China. We are #2 in global commercial Netbooks and in the all-in-one desktop category. We have been #1 in worldwide relationship notebook sales for 2 straight quarters. So that's where we are fruitful, our results. 
So why did we have such a record-setting year? Two key reasons. We had the right strategy of protect and attack, and a strong execution worldwide. First, our strategy. So in both China and the mature relationship, we want to protect our leadership position and our profit pool. In China, we achieved this by increasing profitability by more than 14%. We did this while growing faster than the market in all 4 quarters and reaching a record market share of almost 38%. In addition, our Lenovo Mobile business unit volume grew more than twice faster as the market. And we launched the -- we also launched the new smartphone and tablet products in China and it got -- and so far, we have got very positive feedback.
So in mature markets, we increased segment operating profit by USD $143 million year-on-year. Thanks mainly to our relationship business and, also, SMB sales.
While protecting our profit pool, we also achieved our all-time high market share of 5.5% for the year, making our protect base more like attack. So we outgrew the market every quarter in relationship and in SMB sales. Our transactional business actually grew 31 points more than the market for the year.
So in emerging markets, our strategy is to grow market share, our revenue. In fact, in emerging markets, we are now #1 in worldwide market share, including China. We grew nearly 3x faster than the market, and increased our market share to more than 60% outside of China. In fact, we gained share across all emerging markets. Like in India, we gained 2.2 points year-on-year. And in Russia, 3.5 points year-on-year.
Our Protect and Attack strategy has guided us to strong growth and balanced the performance across the world. So this year, we will continue to execute our strategy, which is protecting China and the mature relationship, and attacking the emerging markets and the mature transaction. 
At the same time, we will also focus on other, some other key areas in our strategy. So in China, we want to expand further into servers and workstations. In mature relationship, we will leverage the ongoing cooperate replacement cycle and capitalize synergies with NEC to drive more growth and profit. Emerging markets, we were improved profitability in countries where we have already reached double-digit market share. And in mature transaction, we are committed to profitable growth. Our positive investment in SMB are now paying off as we grow profitably. We are also interested in the consumer space. But this is certainly a fiercely competitive market, and it will be even more challenging for newcomer. So we have to think in a different way to enter this space.
In addition to our traditional PC business, we also -- we are focused on the mobile Internet space. We have formed a new group, Mobile Internet and the Digital Home business unit to lead the effort. To attack this space, we will fully leverage our expense. Therefore, China and the global commercial markets are our initial focus for the areas. In China, we have already launched the LePhone and the LePad. For this summer, we will launch both the consumer and the commercial tablet products in America and other selected countries. 
To continue our strong growth, we will make strategic investments in building our foundation and the core competitiveness. First, we will continue to invest in innovation. We will center on customer experience and go deeper in research and core component technology. We also -- we'll continue building our own device class service end-to-end platform and ecosystem, particularly in China. Second, so we will continue building a global brand. Our brand must become our strength, and we will improve profitability over time.
Third, we will continue to refine our business model. We will continue to develop our in-house  background building. We will continue to develop our in-house service capabilities and enhance our strategic IT deployment more importantly. So we will further strengthen our transactional capability, which includes identifying opportunity, precise planning and a timely adjustment. So this will help develop even higher efficiency from end to end. So this investment will enhance our core competitiveness for future growth.
So our strategy and execution worked very well last year. But we will not rest. In the year ahead, we remain optimistic about the PC market, as well as the mobile Internet space. We are confident that we have the right strategy and with strong execution, we will continue to achieve sustainable growth. 
So thank you. I'll now turn to Wai Ming, our CFO.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext:
Good evening. Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through very briefly Lenovo financials and the operational performance for quarter 4 and our full fiscal year 2011. 
Next charts, please. Yuanqing had just started to share with you that our fiscal year 2011 performance, which has been a very fantastic -- which is very fantastic for us. Quarter 4 is another solid quarter for us. We continue to outperform the worldwide PC market across the board by geography, by product and customer segments. Our PC shipments growth in quarter 4 was up 16% against the worldwide PC market drop of 1.1% year-to-year. This helped drive our market share for quarter 4 up 1.5 points to 9.9 percentage, and making our market share for the fiscal year increase 1.7 percentage points to 10.2%. 
China continued to regain its growth momentum, and we continued to extend our leadership in China to record high market share ever achieved in quarter 4. With corporate in refreshment cycle continuing its momentum, we continue to lever this cycle to expand our growth in the mature market and this helped to improve our margin as well. 
We grew 7% in mature market against the market decline of 12%. Indeed, we achieved an all-time high market share of 5.7% in the mature markets with improved margins. Meanwhile, our share growth strategy in emerging markets was also working well. We grew at over 2x the market growth, and we'll continue to gain share in the region to 5% -- 5.7% with reduced losses. Our strong product portfolio and services help us to grow faster than the market in both the customer as well as product segments. As a result, our share in commercial market grew by 1.6 points to 13.8%. And in the case of consumer market, we grew at 1.1 point to 6.7%. 
Next charts, please. In quarter 4, we grew 13% year-to-year in revenue to approximately $4.9 billion. PC sales were up 11% year-to-year to $4.7 billion, revenue from the Mobile business at about $187 million, up 43% year-to-year. Gross profit was about $600 million up 34% year-to-year and gross profit margin expanded to 12.3%. The strong margin was due to effective margin management, increased Think product mix and favorable key component prices. The strong margin improvement allowed us to continue our investment in product innovation, branding and marketing for new PC, as well as MIDH products to drive our future growth. 
As a result, operating expenses, including our investments, increased to $531 million. And the E/R ratio was up 10.9%. While our quarter 4 is a typical slow season with less scaling benefit, this is also one of the reasons that our E/R ratio was up quarter by quarter. Nevertheless, we expect the ratio is going to trend down in the next few markets -- in the next few quarters, as we enjoy better scaling benefit from the increased volume in the next few quarters.
Operating profit in quarter 4 was $69 million, up 46% year-to-year. We recorded a non-operating expense of $10 million that relates to net financing cost. Pretax income, $60 million, 3x against $20 million pretax income we recorded last year. We reported a one-off item and restructuring cost of $20 million quarter 4 last year, which related to redundancy costs incurred primarily in mature market. Profit attributable to equity holders is $42 million, up 2.2x year-to-year. 
For the full year, we finished the year with strong sales revenue growth. Revenue was up 30% to $21.6 billion, gross profit up 32% to approximately $2.4 billion, and gross margin expanded slightly to 10.9% from 10.8% last year. We expanded our profit and successfully managed our expenses while we're also invested to drive our long-term competitiveness. 
E/R ratio hit a recent record low level at 9.2%. Pretax income was $358 million, up 103% compared to last year. Please note that we recorded a $68 million one-off item in restructuring cost last year. That one-off item largely is the warranty provision of certain components and parts not reimbursable by supplies. At the same time last year, we also recorded a one-off $83 million gain related to disposal of some listed investments.  Total pretax in this fiscal year -- in fiscal year 2010, was $176 million.
Profit attributable to equity holders for the full year is $273 million, up 111% year-to-year. Basic EPS is USD $0.43 in quarter 4, and USD $2.84 for the year -- for the full year. A final dividend of HKD $0.05 per share is recommended by the board this morning. Together with the interim dividend paid of HKD $0.026 per share, dividends for the fiscal year were amount to a total of HKD $0.076 per share.
Next charts, please. Looking at the balance sheet. Our strong operating performance has also helped our balance sheet and cash flow. Our balance sheet as of March 31 remains very strong. Non-current asset was about $2.8 billion, similar to that of last year. Current asset approximately $8 billion, and the increase compared to last year was due to higher bank deposits and cash flow -- and the improved cash flow. Increase in trade not in other receivable was in line with our increase in business. Current liabilities was at around $8 billion, largely due to increase in account payable, again, which is in line with our increase of our business. 
Overall, the balance sheet remains very strong. Despite quarter 4 is our -- typically is our slow season. We had net current liabilities of around $96 million as of March 31, 2011. The non-current liability were around $838 million.
Next charts, please. Working Capital. Our cash flow continued to be very healthy, and cash conversion cycle further improving in quarter 4. Net cash reserve increased to $2.7 billion against $1.9 billion last year, largely due to increase in sales revenue. While our business model operates on a negative cash conversion cycle, this means in this quarter 4 , we need to settle the account payable in quarter 3 which is much relatively higher, and then we receive the revenue in quarter 4 which is smaller. And that's the reason why we are showing Q-to-Q drop in cash.
We continue to do well in managing our working capital. Our cash conversion cycle in quarter 4 continues to improve to negative 33 days, a further improvement of 5 days compared to the same period last year. Inventory days remained the same at 18 days in quarter 4, while days receivable increased by 2 days to 32 days despite increase in channel sales in overseas markets, especially in emerging market and increase in ocean shipment. Days payable improved by 7 days to 83 days, largely due to increase in our outsourcing to ODMs. The cash conversion cycle for the full year was negative 28 days compared to the negative 30 days last year. Reason for the changes is inventory days, accounts receivable and payables is similar to that, as I explained in quarter 4.
Now let me turn to quarter 4 geographic performance. This chart summarizes the performance by geography for quarter 4. We have excluded restructuring charges and one-off items from the operating profit and margins so that you can better evaluate our performance. China. China market has regained its momentum in quarter 4, driven primarily by growth in the emerging cities in the country. We continue to perform well in China, with unit shipment growth approximately 16% year-to-year, more than 2x the market growth. This resulted in our further increase of our share in the market. According to the preliminary industry estimate, our share for the fiscal year hit a record high of 29.5%. 
PC sales increased 7.7% year-to-year to approximately $2 billion. Strong growth in emerging cities and desktop PC are the main driver for the strong growth in China, but it also resulted a lower ASP, which is average selling price. Nevertheless, our gross margin remains stable. The PC operating margins stayed at about 5%, dropped slightly year-to-year due to increased R&D expenses, as well as selling expenses. We are very confident that the PC margin will remain relatively stable. 
The Mobile business in China continue to be on track. Unit shipment growth was strong at 27.3% year-to-year, and I will cover this in more detail a little bit later. Our 3G smartphone, which is the LePhone business, is progressing well. We are still making investment in product development, marketing and new product promotion to drive future growth. We're also making investment in the launch of our first tablet product, LePad, in March this year. As a result, our overall operating margin in China dropped to 4%. And we expect our investments in the Mobile Internet business will help to drive growth in China over time. 
Looking at emerging markets. Our expansion in emerging markets continue to show good momentum in quarter 4 across all geographies, products and customer segments. New distributors were up 31.5% year-to-year, market share further expanded to 5.7% and up 0.8 points year-to-year. Sales were up 14.2% year-to-year to $850 million, and operating loss narrowed to $10 million both quarter-to-quarter and year-to-year, and we further improve our operating efficiency. 
We are particularly pleased to see that share gains in countries like India, up 2.8 points to 10%; Russias, which is primarily Russia, up 3.5% to 8.9%; ASEAN, up 1.3 points to 6.9%. They are either profitable or breakeven with objective to achieving a stronger and much more prominent market position with sustainable profitability. We continue to invest in branding to drive our volume growth and extend our market share to reach 10% in more key countries.
Looking at the mature market. We continue to record good growth in the mature markets. Unit shipments up 7% year-to-year against the market drop of 12%, boosted by the strong momentum in the commercial business as corporate continued to refresh their machines. 
Market share as a result was up 1 point to 5.7%, and this is the record high market share we ever achieved. In addition, we also maintain our position as the #2 commercial notebook manufacturer and have become the #1 relationship notebook player in the world. North America remained a key market in the region. Unit shipment is up 25.4% and also achieved a record high market share of 5.8%. We're profitable in all countries in the mature region, except for Western Europe. Performance in Western Europe was, however, affected by the weakened consumer sentiment and our relatively small presence in some distribution channels. We endeavor to take actions to improve our consumer business with an objective to improve the overall performance and profitability in Western Europe. 
Sales were up 13.3% to approximately $1.8 billion. Operating profit improved to $36 million from a loss of $6 million a year ago, and operating margin also improved to 1.9% for the quarter. With the continuing improvement of our commercial business in the region, we expect that profitability in this region will continue to improve.
Next charts, please. Looking at by product. From the product perspective, the Desktop business continue to perform well. Unit shipments and sales in our Desktop were up 17%, and 13% year-to-year, respectively. Our market share in worldwide desktop market increased 1.8 points to 10.2%. Our all-in-one products and SMB targeted desktop continue to see good growth momentum, and we were #2 all-in-one producer worldwide in the fiscal year. The all-in-one category has doubled in shipments and it account to approximately 39% of our worldwide consumer desktop product sales in quarter 4. 
Notebook continue to demonstrate good growth momentum through our winning product portfolio. Unit shipments in sales were up 15% and 12% year-to-year respectively. Strong performance in the commercial business helped offset pressure on the consumer business, and the increase Think branded product mix resulted in the high increase in sales. 
Our worldwide market share increased 1.2 points to 9.7 points and have become the #1 relationship notebook player in the world. During quarter 4, we introduce a new wave of ThinkPad Edge products for SMB and the next generation of ultraportable business laptops, further enhancing our Notebook portfolio. 
Finally, Mobile products also showed very strong growth in quarter 4. Unit shipments were up 27% year-to-year. Our feature phone business continued to show strong shipment growth at 24% year-to-year and will remain the largest domestic mobile handset brand in China, with market share up by around 1.5 point year-to-year. Our 3G smartphone, which is LePhone unit shipment, was below 100,000 units in quarter 4, largely due to a slower seasonality. We continue to work closely with the telco operators in China to broaden our distribution coverage in China and enrich our app store platform, which we call LeGarden, to enhance user experience. Yuanqing just shared with you our newly formed organization MIDH group, which will coordinate the overall mobile Internet initiative to drive future growth. 
Before I end my presentation, I want to give you some color on the market outlook. Looking ahead, we are optimistic of the PC market and the mobile Internet space. China and PC market growth will likely to continue to regain momentum in coming quarters on improving market sentiment. The corporate PC refresh cycle will continue its momentum and will continue to leverage this cycle to grow profitably and gain share for the group. 
Similarly, the strong growth momentum in emerging markets that we saw last year will likely to continue. We will continue our solid execution of our Protect and Attack strategy, which will give us a balanced performance to further consistently expand the business scale and improving our margins. We will stay focused on the cost initiative and growth opportunity. We'll continue to invest in our core competence building, product innovation and branding, especially the new MIDH group to drive our future growth. The new MIDH group will coordinate our initiative to drive growth in the mobile Internet business and will continue to launch new products in the smartphone and tablet. 
Even with this investment, we expect our E/R ratio to improve in the next few quarters due to better scaling benefit arising from our increase in volume. We have a very healthy balance sheet, and we'll continue to be prudent in managing our cash to create shareholders value. As well as we will also look for M&A opportunities to accelerate our growth. In the meantime, we will focus on the smooth integration of our joint venture with NEC after we close the transaction at the end of June.
We are very confident that with our well-defined strategy and action plan in place, Lenovo will continue to improve its performance and profitability in the next few quarters. 
Now let me turn to Chairman Liu.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext:
[Chinese] Dear friends, good evening. By this quarter, it has been more than 2 years since the company adjusted the top leadership. 
During the first year following the change, we turned around the business. In the second year, our profit grew substantially against the previous year. Now, we are enjoying a very strong momentum. For 6 consecutive quarters, Lenovo has been the fastest growing one among all of the major PC makers of the world. Our North America and European markets have become very profitable, and our emerging markets have grown market share substantially while staying profitable. 
Our business is very balanced in all geographies, all business units and all product lines. What's most encouraging is that our Think branded product line has become the key driver of our profit, and this result exactly fulfills our original intention of acquiring IBM's PC business. But all of this results I have mentioned are not enough to prove that our acquisition of IBM's PCD is a success. The most effective proof point is the top leadership team who are very united and are working with very good rapport. The team is very determined about goals and works as a good example for the whole staff. 
In addition, across the company, a positive culture has been built. For Chinese employees, as well as employees across the world, their confidence and aspirational spirit are getting stronger and stronger. Given this foundation, the strategies developed by the management will certainly be executed well and with determination. 
In virtually every board meeting, the directors were delighted by the fact that the management overachieved or sometimes well surpassed what they committed. It has been 6 years since Lenovo's acquisition of IBM PCD. We have undergone various hardships, testing and quite a long period of adaptation and integration. Now, we can say proudly and surely that this large-scale M&A has been a success. 
Currently, Lenovo is facing new significant challenges. That is the new demands by our customers for products and services with the emergence of the mobile Internet. Facing such challenges, the board and management of Lenovo are calm, realistic and focused in addressing them. On the other hand, we are taking the challenge as an opportunity with an enterprising and upbeat spirit. Over the years, since establishment especially through the M&A of IBM PCD, Lenovo has accumulated certain R&D capabilities and capital. The board has approved the management's initiative of allocating quite a large proportion of profits of each quarter and each year to invest significantly in brand building and R&D.
Given this foundation, the management will analyze the industry landscape and trends. They would start from a conceptual and a macro perspective, and then move to micro and detailed level. Their analysis and exploration enable them to craft a strategy with phases to achieve technology innovation and the business model innovation. We just established the MIDH business unit, led by an executive with proven track record. 
Starting from this year, we will take China as an arena to make breakthroughs by rolling out a whole new series of products, including smartphones, tablets, smart TV and et cetera. In this new field, we will learn and adjust continuously.
Our strong historical track record and consistent style of doing what we say will give our shareholders, customers, confidence in us. Over time, we will prove to them that we can deliver. Lenovo's vision is to be an endearing, trusted technology business that is well-respected across the world. We are marching towards our preset goals step by step with perseverance and determination. I firmly believe that Lenovo's future will be very bright. Thank you.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: Thank you, Mr. Liu, for your remarks, and Yuanqing and Wai Ming for their presentations. We will take questions from the floor now. [Operator Instructions] Now, may I have the first questions, please?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: This is Arthur Hsieh from UBS. Two questions. First is that in this previous quarter, the March quarter, the Western Europe seem to have a little bit loss. So I wonder how much of that was because of your competitors has stopped the channels and caused your abnormal performance, or is that really a market demand slowdown? And what's your assessment of your, the market demand right now? That's the first question.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: Well, from a standpoint of our business, our strengths are well-aligned to where the markets are strong. We've been winning in the commercial segment, as well as in China across our key segments. In Western Europe, what we saw is some macro economic issues around the Eurozone. Our business performed very well in that space, and in front of that, it actually took share. But because of competitions, long position in inventory, this put pressure in the marketplace. And there was a disproportional amount of inventory in the PC segment across Western Europe. We believe this market will continue to slowly improve as its macroeconomic environment improves. But our business has continued to perform reasonably well in the front of those kinds of pressure. And actually, as we've seen, our commercial business is now #1 in large enterprise and public sector. And we've seen very strong performance across that. And that's why we're investing today to expand a global campaign around for those who do a marketing campaign to lift our brand presence, to create a deeper awareness and consideration for all our product segments in Western Europe and across the emerging market. So in West Europe, I think that the inventory position from our competition was a factor, as well as the macroeconomic environment. But again, we took share, we outpaced the market, and if you reflect on Yuanqing's comment about mature markets, in mature markets, we hit our all-time high for market share and had some of our best profit driven by our Think business, our Think business in both SMB, Small and Medium Business, as well as commercial. This Think business is where our business is strong, and we're seeing strong market performance.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: Next question is about this mobile Internet related investment. If that circulation is correct, I think in the past 2 quarters, you spent around like $19 million, like $22 million each quarter for this related investment. So should we look at this number as normalized run rate into the future, or will you also start to spend this kind of marketing related dollar in R&D in the other regions, as you rollout your mobile Internet products into other regions?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: Well, just as our strengths are aligned to where the market is strong, our investments are clearly in the areas where the market is growing. And you may have noticed that we've seen a step-by-step, quarter-by-quarter improvement in our operations, margins, and our execution across the planet. I didn't mention it earlier, but we saw almost 0.5 million unit improvement in our inventory position over the last quarter, where many of our competitors have seen their inventory position erode. So we're well-positioned for velocity and momentum going forward. I think that's a key factor in terms of the business. Did you want to make any additional comments? The investment of that MIDH. He was talking about $19 million investment. Well, from a standpoint of investment, as our margins improve quarter on quarter, as they've gotten better and better, as Yuanqing and Chairman Liu commented in the presentation, we are taking investments around that global market campaign to build our global brand, as well as to invest in those key business area where the market is growing. The mobile Internet is a key segment. We must lead and gain market share to a leadership position in China. We've leveraged the ecosystem. We begun to build with the LePhone launch last year. And now with LePad in March, we'd continue to expand on that. You'll see us continue to funnel off a portion of investment each quarter to fuel that growth in this key segment.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: So we will continue to invest in Mobile Internet in China, not just in marketing, but also in R&D. So in terms of marketing investment, so why we need to invest so much money? Because now, although Lenovo has very strong brand in China, but our brand is in PC side. So we need to build stronger branding in the phone area, in the Mobile Internet area. So we should build the leadership position in resale in terms of the brand. So that's one. Certainly, we need to invest more on R&D area. But now, I think we have the constraint on the R&D. It's the product development, because we don't have enough results to develop multiple product lines. So we will further invest in this area to ensure we will have more attractive, more competitive products in the market.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: So actually, as you see our revenues continue to grow and our market share position expand, I would expect our investment to continue to expand, whereas as a percentage basis it will go down, but in total dollars it will increase.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: I just want to add one point. I think the way that you try to read the numbers, probably the difference between the segment profit between China and China PC, that is definitely not the right logic of business investment we invest in our MIDH business. I think it's more substantial business, part of our key growth in the future. We actually invest a lot more than that. And the way that you look at the numbers, I think the logic is not correct because in the non-PC business, there are mobile handsets business which is very profitable.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: Next questions, please.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: [Chinese] Good evening, I'm Jiong Shao. I'm from Macquarie. Two questions. First of all, I would like to ask you, previously, there was this earthquake in Japan. How does that affect the supply situation of components? And from now on, in the coming months, what would be the impact on the price of components? That's the first question.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: From Rory Read on the operations side. The March '11's earthquake was a tragic event in Japan. Fortunately, in the quarter that we just completed, all of the parts were already in the supply chain structure. So no impact in terms of supply chain activities. Over the last 2 or 3 weeks of March, we saw some impacts in terms of -- not the core main component, but in the second tier components like disk controllers, smaller chip controller component. And we saw some potential gap within the next quarter's supply. But our product teams and our supply chain has worked very hard in the current quarter. They've closed the supply chain, supply plan, to support our objectives for the quarter. And we do not see any significant impact in terms of the supply chain and our supply plan to support our objectives for the quarter in Japan or anywhere around the world. In terms of pricing, what we did see was some tightness of product components in the first 6 weeks with the quarter. We saw that. And now those component pricing had some small increases. But this is marginal and not impacting our overall growth and objective. So we've seen a very healthy business in our Japan business. It's performed well. And our global supply chain is well-positioned and not feeling any material impact from the earthquake from March '11.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: [Chinese] My second question is about the macro Chinese economic situation. Lately, we're all talking about the economy slowing down. Are you worried about any hard landing? PMI hasn't been very positive. So can you talk about that? What do you see from your perspective? Is it going to slow down? Any significant signs?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: [Chinese] From our perspective, I think things are looking very positive, and we're very confident about the Chinese economy, especially for PC sector. Why is that? Right now, many commodities in China, well, they're already looking at the biggest market but for PC computers, we're only the second largest. U.S. is still the biggest market. But we believe in the coming 2 years, we are going to grow into the biggest market. Concerning PC infiltration rates compared to the United States, there is still a big gap, especially since China is part of the mature market, also part of the emerging market. For the mature market part, it is already saturated. But for medium- to small-sized cities, there is still great potential for growth. So we will pay close attention to this area. Concerning the macroeconomic situation, we're very confident. We believe they will be high-speed development and growth. Although there are some controlled measures on profitability sector, but the impact will be very mild. Chairman?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., 2011 Earnings Call, May 26, 2011
componenttext: [Chinese] In the shorter term, I think there will be some policies affecting every sector. But for the longer term, there's plenty of room to sustain high-speed development of the Chinese economy. For example, the Chinese government has announced clearly that consumption has to be the polling factor for economic growth. Relevant measures have already been implemented. They have been chanting a slogan for quite some time, and we now feel that actual measures have been implemented. So China is going to become the fastest developing market. Chinese and international enterprises will enjoy great opportunities to enter the Chinese market. So if we do this well, the exchange rate of renminbi can be resolved so that the amount of export will not greatly exceed the amount of import. So many problems can be resolved from this angle. So why is there great room for development? We'll have more than 200 million population in the villages. Through urbanization, they will have great demand. In the past, the land and villages could not be transferred. And now there are new policies that land can be transferred. And that means a lot of labor will be released. And they will have great purchasing power. And I know the government has some concepts in mind. Last year, they were making preparation for the '12 5-year plan and some new leaders were coming on board. So from medium to -- maybe in 2 years' time, I think the situation will be very positive. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Hope everyone is off to a great start in the new year. Now, I'm looking forward to discussing our third quarter earnings with you.
Next slide. Once again, we continue to achieve strong results across the world. For the fifth straight quarter, Lenovo is the fastest growing major PC company. We grew 21% year-to-year, more than 6x faster than the market already. Our worldwide market share is 10.2%, up 1.5 points year-to-year. Our balanced growth come from strong performance worldwide. For the first time since the global economic crisis, we have made more than USD $100 million net profit. Overall, our PDI is USD $121 million. 
Our gross margin improved to 11.2%, up almost 1 point quarter-to-quarter. At a glance, this was clearly due to our improved think product mix and the lower component of prices. But looking deeper at the fundamental reason was the right strategy, which I will discuss later. 
As we said last quarter, we increased our investment in marketing, product research and development. This investment will improve our long-term competitiveness. This will push our EBITDA slightly higher quarter-to-quarter. But thanks to efficient operations, we kept our EBITDA ratio near historic lower level at 9%. In terms of growth, PTI gross margin and EBITDA ratio, we achieved another strong performance this quarter. 
Next slide. These results show that our Protect and Attack strategy continues to deliver good results. Our strategy is driving balanced growth worldwide. In the second quarter, we reached double-digit market share in 10 countries. In last quarter, we increased that number to 15 countries. As you will see later, we outgrew the market in all regions, product types and customer segments.
Next slide. Our China business remains very strong, reaching a all-time high of 32% market share. Again, off 2.4 points year-to-year. As you can see from the chart, we grew in a fiercely competitive market, where our competitors were losing market share. Our success comes from strong growth in small cities and rural areas, Large Enterprise business and all-in-one Desktop PCs. 
We outgrew the market by 3x, increasing shipments by 13% year-to-year compared to the market rate of 4%. Our segment profit declined USD $3 million year-to-year. That was due to our large investments in Mobile Internet. Our board and our management team believe that, that is an area crucial to Lenovo's future. If we don't win in Mobile Internet, we will be sidelined even as we continue to grow in PC.
Next Slide. In the rest of the Emerging Markets, growth is the key of our strategy. We grew 43% year-on-year, well ahead of the market trend of 16%. Particularly in India, we reached double-digit market share for the first time. We also grew 3.3 points year-on-year in Russia and close to 1 point in Latin America.
Next slide. Let's talk about the Mature Market. In this market, our key focus is to protect our profit pool and we have seen good results, as the segment operating profit grew USD $29 million year-on-year. What's even more exciting is that our protect looks more like a tax [ph] sometimes. As we become more competitive, we not only make profit, but also continue to gain market share. Our shipments grew 23% year-on-year as the overall market lost 4 points. We gained over 1 point market share year-on-year. 
For the first time, Lenovo has become number 1 worldwide in notebook sales to global Large Enterprise customers, public customers, with 21% market share, and we are now number 2 worldwide player in commercial notebook segment. Particularly, in North America, we grew 29% year-on-year when the overall market lost 4%. In Japan, Lenovo was the fastest growing major PC company for the sixth straight quarter. Our share in Japan is now over 7%, up almost 2 points year-on-year. We expect to further strengthen our position in Japan through our new joint venture with NEC, which I will discuss next.
Next Slide. So this partnership with NEC plays very well with our global strategy. We are confident for several reasons. NEC's strength in commercial and consumer markets fits perfectly with our strategy in Japan. Both Lenovo and NEC are deeply committed to innovation. This partnership will also benefit greatly from our cost signatures. 
After our announcement, I received Japan's largest electronics retailer, Yamada Denki, where NEC products represent 28% of its offering mix. They told me that, as Japan's number 1 PC brand, NEC products are selling at 20% premium over Lenovo products. It is also selling at a higher price than most Japanese multinational brands. The retailers inside the U.S. are even more confident because when NEC products start to use the components at Lenovo's price, our profit will be very substantial. It is not only our stable business, but also can drive significant profit growth.
As you know, with the successful integration of our IBM PC business, we have experience bringing organizations together and creating a unified company. I believe we will benefit from this experience. With our combined share in Japan, Lenovo will now be the market leader in 2 of the world's 3 largest markets.
Next slide. We recognize more and more that Mobile Internet will be an important battlefield. It will have a major influence on the entire PC industry. Fortunately, we are ready for the challenge and we are ready with innovative products. 
To be more competitive, we created a new organization recently. Mobile Internet and the Digital Home. Our efforts have started to pay off. As you can see from last quarter's results, we doubled our sales of LePhone to 230,000 units. At the CES [Consumer Electronics Show], we introduced the LePad and the hybrid notebook U1, which received excellent reviews and media coverage. To further grow in this space, we will continue to invest in development and marketing.
Next slide. Looking forward, we are confident in our future growth based on our competitiveness through our products, business model and culture. Also, we are very confident in our 2 core markets, China and the worldwide Large Enterprise customer business. 
Although the short-term outlook may be moderate, we have full confidence in China's long-term economic growth. We believe that China will become the world's largest PC market soon and our business will grow with the market as well. At the same time, the global economy is recovering, corporate replacement cycle will continue. We like our position and are very optimistic about the future. Thank you. And now, I will turn it over to our CFO, Wong Wai Ming. Wai Ming, please.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo financial and operational performance for our Quarter 3. Next chart please. Yuanqing just shared with you that we have another strong quarter, with balanced growth across geographies and customers and product segments through the solid execution of our strategy. Group sales in Quarter 3 were at $5.8 billion, up about 22% year-to-year. PC sales were up 17% year-to-year to $5.6 billion. Sales from the Mobile business in Quarter 3 were $218 million, up 87% year-to-year if we compare this to its own performance last year prior to acquisition. This is also the third quarter we recorded a full quarter contribution of our Mobile business. 
Gross profit was at $648 million and was up 22% year-to-year. Gross margin was 11.2% in Quarter 3. It was up slightly compared to 11.1% in Quarter 3 last fiscal year, but up by 9 points from 10.3% last quarter. Improvement in gross margin quarter-to-quarter was primarily due to our effective margin management, increase of the Think product mix and softening component prices. 
Operating expenses increased 21% year-to-year to $521 million. This figure included our mobile operation expense, which we did not have in the last year results. We mentioned in the last result webcast that we would increase our investment in product innovation and branding for long-term sustainable growth. In this quarter, we invested in love and [ph] promotion to drive future growth after we restored the supply shortage of display screen in Quarter 2. 
Although the sales volume increase in Quarter 3 helped to achieve better scaling expense, this investment led to an increase in our expense-to-revenue ratio to 9% for Quarter 3. We expect this investment in product innovation and branding will enable us to have a sustainable growth and gradually improve our gross margin over time. Meanwhile, we will continue our emphasis in expense control. 
Operating profit was up 28% year-to-year, with operating margin improved to 2.2% benefiting from better scaling in gross margin. Net financial cost was $4 million derived principally from the interest rate differential between deposit and interest rates and factoring cost. Pretax income was $123 million, up 31% year-to-year if excluding restructuring cost and our pretax income margin improved to 2.1%. We recorded $2 million restructuring costs in Quarter 3. Accordingly, our pretax income after restructuring was $121 million, up 29% year-to-year. 
You may recall that we recorded some one-off expenses of $42 million same time last year. They were provision for non-reimbursable warranty cost for replacing components and past and licensing fees. We also recorded a net gain of $43 million from the disposal of some of our investment during the quarter last year. The group taxation was $21 million and the effective tax rate was around 17%. The lower effective tax rate in Quarter 3 is primarily driven by strong performance in Quarter 3, while the effective rate is normally high in low season like Quarter 4, where the operating margin is expected to be lower. We expect the annual effective tax rate to stay within 25% to 30% in the short term before our operating margin shows a significant improvement.
We reported a net profit of $100 million for the quarter, up 25% year-to-year. This is the first time our net profit reached $100 million level since the financial crisis during financial year '09.
Basic EPS improved to USD $0.0103 from USD $0.0086 last year. Now let's have a look at the balance sheet in the next chart. 
Our balance sheet at the end of December remained strong. Noncurrent asset were around $2.7 billion, which was similar to [indiscernible] March 2010. Current asset was slightly over $8.5 billion against $6.2 billion at 31st March 2010. The increase was due to increase in bank deposit and cash and accounts receivable, which were in line with the increase of our sales. Current liabilities were close to $8.5 billion against $6.4 billion in 31 March 2010. The increase was largely due to the increase of our payable, resulting from an increase in sales and our outsourcing to ODMs.
As a result, we have net current assets of $83 million, as of 31st December against $184 million net current liabilities recorded as 31st of March 2010. Let's go through the cash and working capital in the next chart. 
Net cash reserve continue to improve to $3.2 billion against $2.4 billion of the same corresponding period last year, largely due to increase in sales revenue. We continue to do well in managing our working capital. Days of inventory increased 1 day year-to-year to 16 days. Days receivable increased 6 days to 30 days year-to-year. The increase is largely due to our continued expansion into emerging markets, particularly consumer products through our transaction model, which tend to have a longer credit period and lever inventory [ph] .  We have also increased ocean shipments to reduce costs, which contributed to a high inventory level. 
Meanwhile, we have included the mobile operation, which was not in last year's results. Mobile business typically has a longer receivable level compared to PC. Days payable also increased 6 days to 77 days year-to-year, largely due to increase in our outsourcings to ODMs. 
Next, the cash conversion cycle in Quarter 3 was negative 31 days, similar to negative 32 days last year or negative 26 days in the last quarter.
Next chart, please. This chart summarizes the performance by geography. We have excluded restructuring charges and one-off items from the operating profit and margin so that you can better assess our operating results. China accounts for approximately 46% of growth sales. Sales in China were $2.7 billion, up 18% year-to-year or 2% quarter-to-quarter. PC sales were $2.5 billion, up 8% year-to-year. We recorded $218 million sales from our Mobile business, which was not in last year's results. Lenovo feature phone business continued to do well and our smartphone LePhone also recaptured growth momentum after we resolved the display-screen supply shortage, which we had in the last quarter. 
Operating profit was down slightly year-to-year to $132 million. Operating margin was 4.9%, down from 5.9% year-to-year and down from 5.7% quarter-to-quarter. The drop in operating margin was primarily due to increase in marketing expenses incurred to dry [ph] lower phone business in Quarter 3. Operating margins for the PC business was 5.6%, down from 5.9% last year and 6.1% last quarter. This was due to the increase in selling and marketing expense.
Emerging markets, excluding China, account for approximately 19% of group sales. Lenovo continues to show strong unit shipment growth and share gain across the board in this region. Sales were $1.1 billion, up 34% year-to-year or up 4% quarter-to-quarter. Financial performance continue to improve and operating loss reduced by $4 million quarter-to-quarter but worsened $7 million year-to-year. As part of our attack strategy, we will continue to invest in this region to drive shipment growth and market share to close to 10% in key markets to establish optimal market position and sustainable profit in the future. 
In this quarter, we have 15 countries achieve more than 10% market share, an increase of 5 countries compared to Quarter 2.
Mature markets account for approximately 35% of group sales. We also recorded strong growth and share gain in all major markets in the region. Sales were $2 billion, up 22% year-to-year or down 2% quarter-to-quarter. The increase was helped by the strong growth in commercial business. This is the first quarter all markets in the region recorded operating profit since the financial crisis. With the continuing improvements of our commercial business in the region, our operating profit in Quarter 3 was $22 million and operating margin was 1.1%. Both operating profit and margin were up year-to-year and quarter-to-quarter.
Next chart, please. This chart summarizes the performance by product segments. Desktop performed well in Quarter 3. Unit shipments were up 23% and sales were up 18% year-to-year and it accounted for approximately 35% of our sales. Our market share in worldwide Desktop market increased by 1.9 points year-to-year to 11.1%. Our all-in-one products and SMB-targeted Desktop continue to see good growth momentum. Notebook also saw good growth momentum through our winning product portfolios. Unit shipments grew 19% and sales were up 15% year-to-year. It accounted for around 59% of our sales. Our market share in worldwide notebook market increased by 1.2 points year-to-year to 9.6%. Our newly launched ultra-portable ThinkPad Edge E10 and IdeaPad U260 notebooks, which targeted SMB and consumer client, respectively, further enhanced our notebook portfolio.
Finally, mobile products also showed strong growth during the quarter. If compared to its performance last year, unit shipments were up 52% while sales up 87% year-to-year. This was a result of a very strong growth in our feature phone business, as far as the increased sales from high unit pricing LePhone. Our feature phone business showed strong shipment growth at 39% year-to-year and remained the largest domestic mobile handset brand in China, with market share up by about 1 points year-to-year. 
Our 3G smartphone phone LePhone recaptured growth momentum and we continue to work closely with telco operators to broaden our distribution coverage in China. In order to enhance user experience of LePhone users, we launched LeGarden, which is our application platform during the quarter and will continue to enrich our FStar [ph] platform.
Before I end my presentation, I wanted to give you more color on the market outlook. We remain cautiously optimistic for the worldwide PC market outlook despite macro challenges in global economy and debt crisis in the mature markets. Despite China market showing moderate growth, we expect it to continue to grow faster than the rest of the world in the long term. In addition, the corporate replacement demand, especially in mature markets, will continue to pick up gradually. Growth momentum in the emerging markets would likely continue, as we continue to execute our share growth strategy. We continue to invest in R&D and branding with an objective to drive future sustainable growth and better gross margins. 
And now the area of investment is our Mobile Internet business. We plan to launch our first tablet product, LePad, in China later this quarter and globally in June. We will also be launching our CES award-winning hybrid notebook, which is IdeaPad E1 hybrid later this summer in China. These investments, however, will cost the expense-to-revenue ratio to increase in the short term, especially during Quarter 4, which is typically a low season. And the ratio will normally be higher sequentially compared to Quarter 3.
We announced our NEC transaction in January. NEC currently is the market leader in Japan, which is the third largest PC market in the world. We have started and we'll focus in the integration coverage and work to ensure the planned synergies will be realized. We expect the deal to close on 30th of June this year and we'll start the consolidation in the September end of quarter. In addition to our Protect and Attack strategy will enable us to grow faster in the market, we will continue to look for M&A opportunities within the PC industry to accelerate our growth. Now let me turn to Chairman Liu.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, the board is satisfied with Lenovo's performance in this quarter in all aspects of measurements. For 5 consecutive quarters, Lenovo has continued to be the fastest growing one among all of the world's top PC vendors. Volume, revenue, costs and expenses and pretax income were all delivered, meeting the company's original commitments and targets. This is an excellent result. 
I can recall that since I resumed the chairmanship, each time when I updated investors in the media about the quarter's result, I always intended to explain what the result of that quarter meant. From Quarter 2 to 3, what Lenovo can demonstrate is the balanced development, balance in product mix, geographies and segments. In this quarter, the China market's growth moderated similar to the situation in the last calendar quarter in 2008. In that quarter, as the company's profit was heavily dependent on China, the softening of business in China led to our big financial losses, as well as downsizing and low morale. In this quarter, profits in mature markets are solid. Emerging markets achieved rapid gains of market share while staying profitable. In this way, the company turned in an excellent report card. It indicates that the strategy of Protect and Attack and balanced development formulated by the management has shown its effect.
In this quarter, the expense versus revenue ratio could have been further lowered. And the pretax income could have been 20% more. But the management allocated large amounts of the investments in brand-building and research and development, a move strongly backed up by the board. If the management has conducted rounds of thorough analysis about the industry trend and landscape in the future, we have got a clarified goal for the next and are clear about how to reach that goal with planned phases. I believe that each dollar invested today will bring handsome returns for our investors.
During the board meeting held for this quarter, Lenovo's management gave a report about how the corporate culture and core values of Lenovo, a global company, were formed and cascaded down. In this process, the most important factor is the role of leaders to lead by example. The top management of Lenovo is united, working with very good rapport. They are very capable in enterprising. The whole staff is full of confidence now versus their previous status of only starting to have confidence. Today's Lenovo has become a high-tech company, with a solid, healthy foundation. Due to innovations in technologies, the IT industry will see fierce competition in the next few years, with different players shining in different areas. Lenovo will not be complacent in the face of success, nor will it give up when confronted with failure. It will always work firmly and decisively toward this goal. Thank you.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us. Lenovo had another record-setting quarter. I'm very excited to share our good news with you. So let's get started. Next slide. This quarter, we achieved a record global market share of 12.2%. Record shipments of over 10 million units, and record revenue of USD $5.9 billion, and these 2 milestones brought us back to the top 3 in the global PC industry. For the seventh consecutive quarter, Lenovo is the fastest growing major PC company in the world. We grew at 23%, more than 8x the market rate. While gaining market share, we also continued to improve our profitability with a PTI of USD $123 million, and that is a 64% increase year-on-year. 
As we have said before, we are continuing to invest in innovation and branding for our long-term competitiveness. These investments pushed our overall E/R ratio slightly higher to 10.4%. But they are necessary, and important to our long-term development. So why do we continue to have very strong quarter after another? The reasons are clear, we have the right strategy, and a strong execution worldwide. Next slide. 
Our Protect and Attack strategy continues to guide our strong execution. On the protect side, we continue to strengthen our leadership position in China and in global commercial business. On the attack side, we continued to gain share in emerging markets and in global transaction of business. We also introduced our family of tablets worldwide as we expand our business in the mobile Internet space. So now, let's look at our key areas more closely. 
Next slide. Based on the latest IDC data, China has overtaken the United States as the world's largest for PC market, for the first time. In China, while owning nearly 1/3 of the market share, we outgrew the market by over 9 points. We also increased our segment operating profit by 48% year-on-year. 
Next slide. In the rest of the emerging markets, we continue to outpace the market. We grew 47% year-on-year, more than 3x the market rate. Overall, Lenovo gain 1.5 points of the market share year-on-year. When including China, we strengthened our number one position in global emerging markets, and further distance to ourselves from other competitors. When you look deeper, the story is even better. We gained a share in all emerging market regions, particularly in India where we have gained 3.6 points. We will continue to invest in capturing growth in emerging markets, while focusing on improving profitability. 
Next slide. In mature markets, we continue to improve profitability, while segment operating profit growing USD $56 million year-on-year. At the same time, we continue to outperform the market by growing more than 8% despite the overall market drop. Overall, we reached our record-high market share of 6.6% in mature markets. Our growth was particularly strong in North America, where we grew almost 2 points year-on-year, and reached our record share of 7%. In addition, we have successfully launched our joint venture with NEC in Japan, and completed our acquisition of Medion in Western Europe. Both NEC and Medion will contribute to our business next quarter. More importantly, both will further enhance our competitiveness in these key markets. These are our highlights for different markets. Now, let's look at the Mobile Internet. Next slide. 
This business has made good progress. We sold over 80,000 LePad in China last quarter, and are still ramping up. Globally, we have launched our family of idea and think tablets, targeting different customer segments. Meanwhile, LePhone sales outgrew the market at 172% year-on-year. And last week, we launched our new smartphone, the LePhone A60 to address the one sold in RMB market in China. This is our excellent product at the price points. Next slide. 
In general, over the past 2 years, we have paid more attention to growth, and have invested a lot. This year, as we reached double-digits of market share in more and more countries, we will have a more balanced strategy. While continuing to grow, we will focus more on profitability. We will begin to implement a more country-specific strategy based on our market position. For countries still trying to reach double-digit of share, we will continue to invest in growth. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuangqing. I will take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance in quarter 1. Next chart, please. Yuangqing has just shared with you our strong quarter 1 performance. Growth has, across the board together, we continue improvement in margins even after our investment in innovation, branding, emerging markets and Mobile Internet business. In quarter 1, Lenovo grew 15% year-to-year in revenue to approximately $5.9 billion. This is the highest quarterly revenue we have ever achieved. PC sales were up 15% year-to-year to $5.7 billion. Revenue from the Mobile Internet business was $215 million, up 18% year-to-year. Gross profit was about $739 million, up 41% year-to-year and gross profit margin expanded to 12.5%. 
The strong margin improvement is largely due to better scaling, some fullment price benefits, and increased Think product mix, which allow us to continue our investment in innovation, branding, emerging markets and MIDH to drive future growth. Operating expenses increased to $616 million, which include $98 million in advertising and promotion during the quarter. The E/R ratio was up 10.4%. And we expect the ratio to trend down in the next few quarters, as we enjoy better scaling benefit from unit shipments increases. A continuing investment in branding will help us to improve our brand awareness around the world, which will enable us to further improve our margin. 
Operating profits in quarter 1 was $123 million, up 51% year-to-year. Pretax income was $123 million, up 64% year-on-year. The effective tax rate for quarter 1 was 12%. The lower tax rate was mainly due to better pretax income margin, and the reversal of a $9 million provisions previously made. Profit attributable to equity holders is $108 million, up 98% year-to-year. Now let's look at the balance sheet in the next chart. 
Our strong operating performance has also helped our balance sheet and cash flow. Our balance sheet in quarter 1 remained strong. Noncurrent assets were about $2.8 billion, similar to the level at March 31, 2011. Changes in the current assets and current liabilities were due largely to increased activities during the quarter. We had net current assets of around $38 million at the end of June. The noncurrent liability were at around $875 million let's go through the cash and working capital in the next chart. 
Our cash flow continue to be very healthy and our cash conversion cycle further improved in quarter 1. The net cash reserve continue to improve to slightly above $3.6 billion against $2.2 billion of last year, largely due to increase in sales revenue. We continue to do well in managing our working capital, inventory days improve to 16 days in quarter 1, while days receivable increased by 1 day to 29 days driven by our growth in emerging markets outside China. Days payable improved by 2 days to 72 days, largely due to increase in our outsourcing to ODMs. 
As a result, the cash conversion cycle in quarter 1 improved to negative 27 days against a negative 23 days last year. Next chart, please. 
In the past years, we have been using IBM's IT system in markets outside China, and such IT expenses had been allocated only to mature and the emerging markets. We have now migrated to our own integrated IT system for the entire group operations. Accordingly, starting with the current fiscal year, the IT expenses are allocated to each market segment on a flat-rate basis, with reference to their respective revenue contributions. We consider this basis more appropriate in the measurement of market segment results. The about change in allocation has no impact on the gross operating profit performance. We have, however, restated the historic figures for the like-for-like comparison. Details are set out in the Appendix. 
China. We continue to perform well in China and further expanded our market share. PC sales increased 13% year-to-year to approximately $2.6 billion. Strong growth in the emerging cities and desktop PCs helped drive the strong shipments in China, but also resulted in lower average selling price. Indeed, the PC operating margin improved to 6.4% due to better scaling, and stringent expense control. We are confident that the PC margin will remain relatively stable going forward. 
The Mobile Internet business in China is making progress. Our 3G smartphone, LePhone business is progressing well, but we are still making investment in product development, marketing, and new products promotion to drive future growth. Even with these investments, our overall operating margin in China expanded to 5.6% in quarter 1. 
Emerging markets, excluding China. Our expansion in emerging markets continue to show good momentum in quarter 1. Sales were up 26% year-to-year, to slightly above $1 billion, and operating loss remained relatively stable at $22 million. 
Mature markets. We continue to record good growth in the mature markets, helped by the strong commercial business. Sales were up 13% to slightly above $2 billion. Operating profits improved to $76 million, and operating margin also improved to 3.7% for the quarter. Next chart, please. 
From the product perspective, both notebook and desktop outperformed the markets. Unit shipments and sales in our desktop business were up 23%, and 18% year-to-year, respectively. Our market share in the worldwide desktop market increased by 2.4 points to 12.3%. Our all-in-one products and SMB-targeted desktops, as well as our sales in China, continue to see good growth momentum. 
Notebook unit shipments and sales were up 23%, and 14% year-to-year, respectively. The commercial business was especially strong. Our worldwide market share increased 1.7 points to 12.1%, and we maintain a leading position in the worldwide commercial notebook markets. 
Finally, sale for mobile Internet products were up 18% year-to-year. Total mobile achieved unit shipments growth at 34% year-to-year. Our future phone business continues to do well, and our 3G smartphone, LePhone, also shows strong growth as Yuangqing said earlier. 
Before I end my presentation, I want to give you some color on the market outlook. Despite the current volatility in the global financial markets, we may have an impact on the global economy, we remain confident on continuing our trend of outperforming the worldwide PC market. We are executing our "Protect and Attack" strategy well. As a result, our core business are performing well, and our strategic investment are laying the foundation for future growth. We will continue to benefit from growth in China, and in emerging markets, as well as to continue corporate refreshment cycle in the mature markets. 
We will stay focused on the cost initiatives and growth opportunities. We'll continue to invest in core competence building, product innovation, branding, emerging markets, expressly, the new MIDH group to drive our future growth. Even with these investments, we expect E/R ratio to improve in the next few quarters due to better scaling benefit arising from the unit shipments increase. 
We have a healthy balance sheet. We will continue to be prudent in our cash management to create shareholders' value, and look for M&A opportunities to accelerate our growth. Our strategy is to drive shipment growth, and at the same time, to improve profitability over time. We are confident that with our well-defined strategy and action plan in place, we continue to outperform the worldwide PC market, and our investment in branding, as well as our stringent expense control, we'll continue to improve our margin. 
Now, let me turn to Chairman Liu.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttext:
The board is very satisfied with Lenovo's first quarter results. The highlights is the performance of our mature markets. In this quarter, the mature markets contributed USD $77 million of pretax income, becoming a major contributor to the company's profit. While in the same period of last year, mature markets had a loss of USD $9 million. This is a major improvement in just 1 year. Lenovo's pretax income for this quarter is USD $123 million, a 64% year-on-year increase, and this was achieved despite our average increasing investments in R&D and brand building. So mature markets has made significant contribution to this result. 
For 7 consecutive quarters, Lenovo has been the fastest growing one among the world's top 5 PC vendors. In this quarter, its growth rate is 8x of that of the worldwide market. During the past 7 quarters, the global economic environment, and the PC industry have undergone significant changes. The world economy experienced drastic ups and downs, and China's PC market also fluctuated, even though it has generally maintained an upward trend. 
The competition within this industry has been fierce. Profit margin has been getting thinner, and suppliers have not been stable. Any of these factors could be used as an excuse for failures or misses in our business performance, but we have not had any misses or failures. 
Since early February 2009 where we adjusted our leadership team, our business has turned around. In the initial 3 quarters right after the change, we made adjustments, and fixed some historical issues. Since then though, we have not experienced any sharp ups and downs. We have made consistent progress in shipment volume, revenue, market share and pretax income. Our business is climbing up and everything has been executed well according to original plans. 
Lenovo has an outstanding top leadership team, a correct approach of developing strategies, and strong execution capabilities. This quarter again proves this. It also proves that Lenovo's acquisition of IBM's PC business has become a success. In future quarters, you will see clearly that we will apply our learning from this acquisition into our joint venture with NEC in Japan, and our acquisition of Medion in Germany. 
In this quarter, there's one thing which investors have not paid enough attention to, while I deem it very important. In June, CEO Yang Yuanqing representing the management team, purchased 800 million shares of the company from Legend Holdings through personal financing. This made him the second largest shareholder of Lenovo. He represents not only Yuanqing's confidence in Lenovo, but it is a great example of one of our most important management concepts. We always advocate that top leaders, those who are ambitious and capable, should be the company's few owners. And we are very determined to put some financial arrangements in place to ensure that they will have that mentality, under Lenovo's parent Legend Holdings. 
In addition, to Lenovo, there are other subsidiaries: Digital China, focusing on software service and IT product input; Letting Capital, focusing on venture capital investment; Hony Capital, a PE investment firm; and Recom real estate. Today, all of them are the leading players in their respective industries in China. 
I think that one important reason for our repeated successes is that we select the right leader of a company, and build a platform for him with the foundation of true financial ownership. Yang Yuanqing is an enterprising leader with outstanding capability and bold aspirations. He took the risk of having to pay back loans to buy large amounts of Lenovo shares to become its second largest shareholder. This has fundamental implications, and meaning for Lenovo's development. 
There are 2 types of management teams. First, there are those who act only as hired hands. They make short-term decisions, and are not personally invested in the long-term future of a company. Companies led by this sort of manager, do not do well in the long-term. Then, there are those who are owners and have a personal stake and a long-term mentality about company strategy. This is the type of manager we have at Lenovo. They are owners and entrepreneurs. I can tell you that it is very easy to see immediately which kind of manager is running a company, simply by looking at how they approach business, and what attitude they have in their decision-making. This is why I think Yuangqing's personal investment is so important to Lenovo, now, and for the future. 
Legend holdings, the Lenovo Board, and the Lenovo Management Team represented by Yuangqing are grateful to each other for creating an environment where ownership and commitment are so supported and valued. This feeling will extend to be among our management and the staff over time as well. 
In China, people emphasize that a success is based on the combination of the right timing, right location, and right people. It is hard to control the timing and location factors, but for the people factor, Lenovo has got all of the advantages it deserves, and should have against its competitions. Thank you.

componenttext:
Good afternoon. Welcome to the webcast of Lenovo's Q2 in fiscal 2012 earnings announcement. This is Gary Ng, VP in Investor Relations at Lenovo. Before we start, let me introduce our management team with us today. First, Mr. Liu Chuanzhi, Chairman of Lenovo; our CEO, Mr. Yang Yuanqing; and our CFO, Mr. Wong Wai Ming.
