headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us. I'm very excited about another record-breaking quarter. But today is also important for another reason. On behalf of Lenovo and on a personal level, I want to talk about Chairman Liu. Today, he announced that he will step down as Lenovo Chairman to focus on new opportunities and bold new goals at Legend Holdings. Clearly, he is the founder of our company and is the architect of our business and our culture. I'm honored that with his support, I have been asked to lead Lenovo as both the Chairman and the CEO. This will ensure consistency in our strategy, our culture and our execution.
As I take on this new role, I will follow the footsteps of a great business visionary. I will continue to learn from him and build on what he has created. We will continue to have the same management principle, the same culture of ownership and the same long-term aspiration for Lenovo. I know that Legend Holdings will now be his focus, but Lenovo will always be part of Chairman Liu and Chairman Liu will always be part of Lenovo. I want to thank Chairman Liu for all he has done for our company, and we look forward to making him even more proud of Lenovo for many years to come.
Now onto our great second quarter. We have been the fastest-growing major PC company for 8 quarters. This quarter, we grew by 36% year-on-year, 7x the market rate; achieved a record market share of 13.5%, record shipments of 12.5 million units and record revenue of USD $7.8 billion. We outgrew the market in almost every region, every customer segment and every product segment.
In the last 2 quarters, we have made 2 unbelievable steps forward: surpass both Acer and Dell and reached another important milestone, from #4 in PC market to #3, and now, #2 for the first time. While gaining market share, we continued to improve our profitability. Our net earnings increased by 88% year-on-year to reach more than USD $144 million. And as we have said before, we are continuing to build our long-term competitiveness by investing in innovation and branding. Even so, our E/R ratio dropped almost 0.5 points quarter-to-quarter.
Now let's look at each of our strategic areas more closely. In China, the world's largest PC market, we continue to extend our lead. We outgrew the market by more than 10 points while increased our segmented profit by 35% year-on-year.
As an already dominant player in China, this is truly an impressive performance. But we will not stop there, and we will continue to drive for more growth and better profitability in China.
In the rest of the Emerging Markets, we once again reached a new record-high market share of 8%. We grew 38% year-on-year, more than 3x the market rate. With this, we further strengthened our #1 position in global emerging markets. More impressively, we gained share in every region. Particularly in India, we gained 3.5 points year-on-year. And in Russia, we grew more than 2 points to reach double-digit market share for the first time.
Our focus in Emerging Markets is to continue investing share growth. Meanwhile, for the countries that have reached double-digit market share, we drive for profitable growth.
I'm especially proud of the performance of Mature Markets. We had a fantastic quarter. We delivered almost USD $100 million, more than double our segment profit year-on-year, and we are profitable in all regions. More impressively, for the first time, Mature Markets contributed more revenue than China did.
While we increased the profit and revenue, we also gained share in all mature markets to reach our record-high market share of over 9%, especially in North America where we have returned to the top 5 PC companies in United States.
In addition to strong organic growth, our acquisition activities have also contributed this excellent performance as well. Both of our integrations with NEC and Medion have been successful. Both of these additions are bold moves in line with our strategy.
In most M&A cases, business will drop after the merge. However, our business not only did not slow down, but actually grew faster than the respective market rates while making decent profit in the first quarter after closing. Now we are #1 in Japan and #3 in Germany.
These excellent results demonstrate that M&A has become a core competence of Lenovo. We know what kind of companies to acquire, and we have the knowledge and the experience to integrate them.
Outside of the traditional PC area, we also had very encouraging performance from our Mobile Internet business, which we view as the extended PC family. We continue to see strong LePad sales in China, more than doubled our sales volume quarter-to-quarter. We shipped 168,000 units last quarter. Now we are the #2 player in China market, with significant lead over all other Android-based competitors. Outside of China, we launched both Idea and Think tablets. Our enterprise-focused ThinkPad tablet has received very good feedback.
Meanwhile, our smartphone business again outgrew the market and gained 1.6 points of the market share in just one month. This growth was fueled by our newest smartphone, the Lenovo A60, which has increased its weekly run rate by 4x since launch. We expect our Mobile Internet business to continue its strong momentum in the upcoming holiday season.
Clearly, our Protect & Attack strategy is working very well. In addition, diverse talents, global culture, business model and innovation are also our success factors. I truly believe that Lenovo is one of the most diverse companies in the world. Our Lenovo Executive Committee, comprised of 9 members, comes from 6 countries. And because of our success, more global talents are joining us. Recently, Mr. Gianfranco Lanci, the former CEO of Acer, joined us as a consultant. And we also welcomed Idei-san, the former chairman of Sony, to join our Board.
Even with operations in over 160 countries, we are able to create a truly powerful and unified global culture, which is based on ownership spirit. Do what we say and own what we do.
Our do business model [ph], which caters toward the specific needs of a relationship and the transactional clients just got even more support from our vertical integration move. Last quarter, we announced a joint venture with Compal for our notebook production. This move will greatly enhance our vertical integration effort.
And a good strategy and a talented team still need equally attractive products to make it work. At Lenovo, we are very proud of our innovation capability and achievements. Our results speak for themselves. Most specifically, we have successfully passed HP to become the #1 player in worldwide commercial notebook space, and passed Dell to become the #2 in worldwide overall desktop segment, as well as #3 in global consumer sales. And we won't stop there, as we are managing towards our aspiration.
Looking ahead, we are deeply committed to continue building our core competitiveness and investing in branding and innovation. By doing so, we will further improve our GP margin and increase our PTI.
Overall, we are very optimistic about the future of the PC industry and are fully committed to the whole PC industry for the long run. Not only we want to become the leader in traditional PC market, but also we are confident that we will accomplish much more in those extended PC categories such as tablet and the smartphone.
Thank you, everybody. I now turn to Wai Ming.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance for the fiscal second quarter. Next chart, please.
Yuanqing just shared with you that we have had another milestone quarter, with balanced growth across geographies, customer and product segments through the solid execution of our strategy.
Group sales in quarter 2 were at $7.8 billion, up about 35% year-to-year. PC sales were up about 32% year-to-year to $7.3 billion. We have consolidated a full quarter of revenue from NEC joint venture and 2 months revenue of Medion in the quarter 2 PC sales revenue. Excluding NEC and Medion, we had over 25% year-to-year shipment increase.
Revenue from the Mobile Internet business was $282 million, up 30% year-to-year. Gross profit was at $948 million, up about 60% year-to-year. Gross margin was 12.2% in quarter 2, up from 10.3% last year, but dipped slightly from 12.5% last quarter.
The slight quarter-to-quarter dip is largely due to increasing consumer business after including NEC joint venture and Medion. The year-to-year margin improvement is largely due to better scaling and increased Think product and geography mix, which allowed us to continue our investment to drive future growth.
Operating expenses increased to $782 million, which included $146 million in advertising and promotion during the quarter. We expect this investment in marketing will help us to improve our brand awareness around the world, which enable us to further improve our margin over time.
The E/R ratio was 10%, up from 8.4% last year, but was lower quarter-to-quarter. We expect the ratio to trend down in the next few quarters as we enjoy better scaling benefit from revenue increase, resulting from unit shipments' growth.
Operating profit in quarter 2 was $166 million, up 55% year-to-year. Pretax income was $165 million, up 62% year-to-year. The effective tax rate for quarter 2 was 12.3%. The lower tax rate was mainly due to better PTI margin and reverse of provision previously made.
Profit executable to equity holders was $144 million, up about 88% year-to-year. Basic EPS improved to USD $1.41 from USD $0.81 last year. The Board of Directors today meeting declared an interim dividend of HKD 0.038 per share, representing an increase of approximately 46% compared to last year.
Next chart, please. Our strong operating performance has also helped our balance sheet and cash flow. Our balance sheet in quarter 2 remain strong. Non-current assets were about $3.8 billion. The increase from that of 31st March 2011 was due to consolidation of NEC JV and Medion into our balance sheet this quarter.
Changes in current assets and current liabilities were due largely to increased activities during the quarter. We had net current assets of around $134 million at the end of September. The non-current liabilities were at around $1.6 billion.
Next chart, please. Our cash flow and cash conversion cycle continue to be very healthy in quarter 2. The net cash reserve continued to improve to about $4 billion, against $2.3 billion last year, largely due to increase in sales revenue. We continue to do well in managing our working capital.
Inventory days improved to 1 day in quarter 2, while days receivable increased by 5 days to 33 days, largely due to consolidation of NEC JV and Medion this quarter and our growing Emerging Markets outside China.
Days payable improved by 2 days to 71 days, largely due to increase in our outsourcing to ODMs. As a result, the cash conversion cycle in quarter 2 was at negative 20 days against negative 26 days last year.
Next chart, please. We are even more balanced in terms of geography after we consolidated NEC joint venture and Medion.
China. We continue to perform well in China and further expanded our net market share. PC sales increased 21% year-to-year to approximately $2.9 billion. Strong growth in emerging cities and desktop PCs helped drive the strong shipments in China, but also resulted in lower average selling price. Indeed, the PC operating margin improved year-to-year to 5.6% due to better scaling and stringent expense control. We are confident that the PC margin will remain relatively stable going forward.
The Mobile Internet business in China is making progress. Our 3G smartphone and tablet business is progressing well, but we are still making investment in product development, marketing and new product promotion to drive future growth.
Emerging Markets excluding China. Our expansion in Emerging Markets continue to show strong momentum in quarter 2. Sales were up 21% year-to-year to $1.3 billion, and operating loss remained relatively stable at $23 million. We continue to invest in growth, which resulted in a decline of margin of 0.7 points to negative 1.8%. However, we began to see progress made in the Emerging Markets. As reported by Yuanqing earlier, certain major regions have already exhibited 10% market share.
Mature Markets. We continue to record good growth in the mature markets helped by the strong commercial business. Sales were up 61% year-to-year to slightly above $3.3 billion. We have included a full quarter performance of NEC joint venture and 2 months performance of Medion in quarter 2. Both have performed better than their forecast and contributed profits to the region.
Operating profit improved to $95 million, and operating margin also improved to 2.9% for the quarter. The quarter-to-quarter dip in margin is largely due to the increasing consumer business, after including NEC joint venture and Medion.
Next chart, please. From the product perspective, both notebook and desktop outperformed the market. Notebook unit shipments and sales were up 35% and 30% year-to-year, respectively. The commercial business was especially strong. Our worldwide market share increased 2.8 points to 13.3% and became the largest worldwide commercial notebook player.
Unit shipments and sale in our desktop business were up 36% and 38% year-to-year, respectively. Our market share in worldwide desktop market increased by 3.5 points to 13.7%. Our all-in-one products and SMB-targeted desktops, as well as our sales in China, continued to see good growth momentum. We became the world's second largest desktop player.
Finally, sales of mobile internet products were up about 30% year-to-year. Our mobile phone business, including feature phones and 3G smartphone business, continued to do well. Our tablet products also show strong growth. As Yuanqing said earlier, we're #2 in the China tablet market, with around 8.4% market share.
Before I end my presentation, I want to give you some color on the market outlook. Despite the current volatility in global financial markets, which may have an impact on the global economy, we remain confident in continuing our trend of outperforming the worldwide PC markets. We believe the balanced nature of our growth that helped our strong performance in the past several quarters that is China, emerging market and corporate refreshment demand, will continue to enable Lenovo to outperform and outpace our peers.
Based on the initial assessment of our October performance, we continue our growth momentum in China, Emerging Markets and Mature Markets. Nevertheless, the recent flood in Thailand impacting global supply of hard disk drives would likely affect the PC supply in the short term. We have already taken actions to try to mitigate the potential impact. The abrupt distortion in the supply will however inevitably result in cost increase in hard disk in the short-term, and we will continue to monitor the situation closely. We will prioritize our customers, but also monitor very closely the cost efficiency.
We will stay focused on the cost initiatives and growth opportunities. We will continue to make opportunistic investment, i.e., to use additional profits above our internal targets to fund investment in core competence building such as product innovation, branding and in Emerging Markets, especially in the new MIDH group to drive our future growth.
Notwithstanding this investment, we expect our E/R to improve in the next few quarters due to better scaling and benefits arising from the unit shipment increase. We have a healthy balance sheet. We will continue to be prudent in our cash management to create shareholder's value and look for M&A opportunities to accelerate our growth.
Now let me turn to Chairman Liu.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttext:
[Next is the translation of Chairman Liu's remark.]
Ladies and gentlemen, Lenovo's performance in this quarter is outstanding despite significant investments for future growth. Its PTI increased and over achieved targets. The management developed strategies in a right away and built a solid corporate culture, and the morale of the whole staff is very high. The board is very satisfied.
When looking back on Lenovo's history, it was 1990 when the company started making computers bearing its own brand. Through our journey, we have experienced 3 critical challenges or 3 watershed moments.
The first challenge was in the early 1990s, when China opened its PC market by lowering import tariffs and canceling the quota system. So foreign PC giants started to occupy the China market. Domestic players were not able to compete and fight back. Lenovo was a very small company dwarfed by multinationals like IBM and Compaq in terms of technology, capital, management capability and talent.
In 1994, Lenovo reviewed itself and identified its own weaknesses and then implemented major reforms on organizational structure and business models. We selected the then 29-year-old Yang Yuanqing as the General Manager of the newly founded PC business unit. Since then, the results have been truly miraculous.
Lenovo started with no more than 2% market share in China and then managed to increase it to be 27% in 6 years and has been firmly holding the #1 position in China and even Asia-Pacific. Only people who are involved in this process know that the capabilities and wisdom Lenovo earned through this process were earned through sweat, tears and even blood. What Lenovo got at this point was not only just market share and profits, but also the capability of learning and understanding the insights and know-how of the industry.
We also developed the ability to continuously build the foundation of the company. At the same time, it got a motivated capable team, as well as leaders of divisions and business units headed by Yang Yuanqing.
The second challenge was in the mid-1990s when Dell started to enter and develop in China and Lenovo's shares started to drop. With its innovative business model, Dell conquered the U.S. and European markets. In the China market, Lenovo battled hat-to-hat against Dell for 3 hard years. I remember that the industry insiders and media all thought that Lenovo faced a killer enemy at this time.
After 2 rounds of failures, in the third year, that was 2004, Lenovo won the battle with its bold deployment of new business models and excellent execution. This battle and its win has very fundamental implication for Lenovo because it provided confidence for Lenovo's expansion into the global market, built the foundation for the duo business model and developed a group of capable leaders. Yang Yuanqing at this point became an experienced leader and CEO who knew how to learn from past experiences.
The third challenge was the acquisition of IBM's PC business in May 2005. When we decided to go for it, observers in the media thought it was a typical case of a snake swallowing an elephant, and our possibility for success was very slight.
Prior to the acquisition, Lenovo China's Board and management did thorough analysis and evaluation. Why would IBM sell this business? Why has IBM lost money in this business unit and we could turn it around? What did we want to get? The brand, technology and global resources? What are the major risks? The risk that customers will not buy in the ThinkPad brand under a new owner, the risk of losing employees and the risk of cultural collision. We had plans in place for all of this. In retrospect, it is very important to think things over and have a clear idea. Yang Yuanqing was already an outstanding CEO, but to manage an international company is different than managing a Chinese one. So in the beginning, we insisted on hiring an international executive to be our CEO and Yuanqing was the Chairman.
With the attitude of respecting and compromising, Yang Yuanqing observed and learned how to be a good CEO of an international company. However, culture integration and adaptation, which means how people from different backgrounds, companies and countries get along with each other and work together was crucial to our early development. This is a live issue in the real world, rather than something theoretical.
In the integration and adaptation, collisions were inevitable, and a nice person may not necessarily end up working happily with another person. In this special international company, we had to decide how the Chairman worked with the CEO and how the Board handles the conflicts between the 2. These are all of the issues in cultural integration and adaptation and a tough challenge we used to face.
The worldwide financial crisis in 2008 was the trigger factor of Lenovo's financial losses. We adjusted the Board and the top management team and embarked on a new journey. I'm sincerely thankful for the previous 2 CEOs who passed valuable experience in international business management to Yuanqing and developed a large group of international managers. I'm very grateful for our board members who are fair, candid, loyal and committed. On one hand, they stick to principles. On the other hand, they will take advices to make relevant changes.
Given this foundation, we got a new united board which prioritized the company first. Yang Yuanqing built a solid outstanding top leadership team, and we finally succeeded in handling the cultural integration and adaptation. In this year, our partnership with NEC PC and Germany's Medion have been very smooth, and the success was because of this foundation.
In summary, Lenovo had undergone extreme hardships and risks, but we successfully survived and passed the 3 milestone type of test. As you have heard by now, I'm announcing my retirement from the position of Chairman of the Board of Lenovo. The Board has accepted my proposal and has appointed Mr. Yang Yuanqing as the Chairman. And at the same time, he will continue his CEO role.
I would like to highlight several points of this announcement. First, during the past 7 years, after acquiring and integrating IBM's PC business, Yang Yuanqing has grown through various challenges and tasks and is now fully qualified for the role of Chairman of the global company. In addition, he's an outstanding CEO in our industry. Under his leadership, Lenovo will climb and reach higher and higher summits.
Secondly, several months ago, Yang Yuanqing purchased 8% of Lenovo's shares from its parent company, Legend Holdings, through personal financing. This shows that he is fully confident and motivated about the prospect of the company. He's one of the true owners of this company. As Lenovo's founder and representative of its major shareholder, I wouldn't retire from this position without full confidence, certainty and thoughtful arrangements.
Thirdly, in the future, Lenovo will face challenges in the mobile Internet area. However, Yang Yuanqing is heading a united, extremely capable global leadership team. He masters the right approach of developing strategies and executing them well and enjoys a strong corporate culture as the foundation.  Given this culture, employees love this company.
Based on the above-mentioned 3 points, I believe Lenovo will take challenges with calm and confidence and leverage all of the strengths it has accumulated over the years. It will divide its goal into different phases, tackle different regions in different priorities. And finally, we will be among the leading players in this industry.
Again, based on the above-mentioned 3 points, Lenovo will not be complacent in front of short-term success, nor will it be defeated by failures. Even though we are far from our goal, we will march forward with determination. Lenovo will become a great company and an enduring one with limitless future.
As the founder and Honorary Chairman, I will love this company in the same way I cherish my own life. As the Chairman and President of its parent company, we will be willing and ready to provide all necessary support to Lenovo at any time. I know Lenovo will continue to soar to new heights and achieve all of its dreams and aspirations.
Thank you.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttext: I have 2 questions. First question is directed for Wai Ming. Of the $100 million dollars in synergies from NEC consolidation, how much of it has been reflected in the quarter? headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttext:
So let me just comment on the NEC. Obviously, the $100 million is on an annual basis. I think that is our initial assessment of the total synergies that we can derive from the NEC acquisition -- the NEC joint venture. I think we're actually on track. We will continue to drive more synergy. I think apart from the, I think from the global supply chain, the material, the component side, we obviously will consolidate further, I think, how to improve the efficiency that there are obviously more synergies that can come out. As Yuanqing just mentioned, we obviously have a number of action in place I think, first of all, to secure the supply. But no doubt that there will be an increase in cost or pressure, increase in cost. So we obviously would want to balance -- I think, as Yuanqing also said, that we obviously take profitability in mind. We will make sure that, I think on one hand, that maybe hard disk actually have an increasing cost. We obviously will drive very, very hard to have a cost improvement in other areas. As a whole, our objective remain that we want to maintain the overall margin of the operation.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttext: Yes. So I want to repeat Wai Ming's answer. So definitely, hard drive cost will be increased, but we will drive other component cost down to balance the overall material cost. So we are confident that we will keep the market share. So no problem on that. But try their best to maximize the profitability. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttext: And also, I have a follow-up back to the PC market. As you mentioned, a lot of growth in China is actually coming from the low-tier cities. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttext: Yes, this is exactly our strategy in China. So we actually split the China market by Mature Markets at hand, and Emerging Markets as well. So Tier 1 to Tier 3 are the matured markets. And The Tier 4 to Tier 6 are the emerging cities. So we actually have the higher market share in the emerging cities. So because we have been always the pioneer to develop the lower-tier cities, so we benefited from that. So Wai Ming, do you have the effect on that one?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttext: Yes, I have. I think that in the -- obviously, in the emerging -- China emerging is about 35%. China mature is 65%. We're roughly -- just a reminder, this is not talking about China market as a whole, because it's really talking about the consumer business in China, which I think for us is 35-65. And again, if you really look at the IDC number, the emerging city obviously has a much higher rate. And if I may quote the IDC number, I think in 2012, I think the IDC number is growing 20%. The mature city is growing about 14%. And really, going forward, it's about 30%, 26%, 25% 3, 4 years out. So our unique market share position or leading position in the emerging cities, which in our own terms called China Emerging Markets, is actually giving us a very strong engine for our growth. And bear in mind that I think this is really one of the drivers, that China in the first quarter of this calendar year, bypassed U.S. being the largest market and at the moment, is still showing a high growth. And one of the main driver of the high growth, apart from the general growth in the economy, is really the PC penetration that primarily come out from the China Emerging Market. And adding to your question, which obviously this -- I think that there is a sort of trade-off is on one hand, while we have a tremendous high growth in the Emerging Market, I think they tend to have a little bit more desktop rather than notebook. componenttext: So our overall emerging market strategy in the current stage is still to invest. So we want to drive more market share.
